kb_name: Compliance Agent Golden KB (C&AG Compliance Auditing Guidelines)

source_document.title: Compliance Auditing Guidelines – C&AG of India

entries.title: What is a Compliance Audit?
key_points: Assessment of adherence to applicable laws, rules, regulations, orders, and instructions
Focuses on reporting deviations, weaknesses, propriety, accountability
entries.content: Compliance audit is an assessment of whether applicable laws, rules, regulations, orders, and competent authority instructions are being complied with. It promotes accountability, transparency, and good governance by reporting deviations, identifying weaknesses, and assessing propriety.

entries.title: Objective of Public-Sector Compliance Auditing
question_intents: what is the objective of compliance audit
what is the goal of compliance audit
key_points: Assess activities and transactions against governing authorities
entries.content: The objective of public-sector compliance auditing is to assess whether activities, financial transactions, and information comply (in all material respects) with the authorities governing the entity. It supports accountability and deterrence and includes both regularity and propriety dimensions.

entries.title: Regularity vs Propriety (Critical Distinction)
key_points: Propriety: ethical conduct + sound financial management principles
entries.content: Regularity means adherence to formal criteria from relevant laws, regulations, and agreements. Propriety means adherence to sound public-sector financial management and ethical conduct, ensuring legality and competence even where actions appear formally compliant.

entries.title: How Rules/Regulations are Evaluated in Compliance Audit
question_intents: how to assess rules and regulations
what checks are done in compliance audit
entries.content: Compliance audits evaluate whether rules and instructions are legal, adequate for control and safeguards, transparent and unambiguous, prudent and judicious, and effective in achieving objectives. They also examine whether rules and instructions are consistent with each other.

entries.title: Core Elements of a Compliance Audit
question_intents: what are the components of compliance audit
key_points: Three parties: auditor, responsible party, intended users
entries.content: Compliance audit contains three core elements: (1) three parties—auditor, responsible party, intended users; (2) subject matter (information/condition/activity evaluated); and (3) authorities and criteria used to assess compliance.

entries.title: Authorities vs Criteria (How the Audit Measures Compliance)
question_intents: what are authorities in compliance audit
key_points: Authorities: Constitution, Acts, Laws, rules, regulations, contracts, codes, sanctions
Criteria qualities: relevant, reliable, complete, objective, understandable, comparable, acceptable, available
entries.content: Authorities are the governing sources (Constitution, laws, rules, regulations, contracts, codes, sanctions, policy). Criteria are the benchmarks derived from authorities and must be relevant, reliable, complete, objective, understandable, comparable, acceptable, and available to support consistent evaluation.

entries.title: Compliance Audit Process (End-to-End Flow)
entries.content: Compliance audit follows a structured flow: (1) general principles and annual compliance audit plan, (2) planning individual compliance audits (objective, scope, strategy, criteria, risk, materiality), (3) performing audit and gathering evidence, (4) evaluating evidence and forming conclusions, and (5) reporting and follow-up.

entries.title: General Principles (How Auditors Must Work)
question_intents: what principles apply in compliance audit
key_points: Code of ethics (integrity, independence, objectivity, confidentiality, competence)
entries.content: Auditors must apply professional scepticism and professional judgement throughout the audit. Audit teams must have appropriate competence, follow ethical principles (integrity, independence/objectivity, confidentiality, competence), implement quality control, manage audit risk/materiality, document work sufficiently, and maintain effective communication.

entries.title: Audit Risk and Materiality (How Severity is Judged)
question_intents: how to decide material non compliance
key_points: Audit risk types: inherent, control, detection
Materiality influenced by public interest, fraud, legislative focus
entries.content: Audit risk is the risk of an inappropriate conclusion and includes inherent risk, control risk, and detection risk. Materiality depends on professional judgement and includes quantitative and qualitative aspects. Matters like fraud, concealment, unlawful acts, and legislative/public sensitivity can be material even without high monetary value.

entries.title: Audit Evidence (Sufficiency and Appropriateness)
key_points: Reliability stronger when external, direct, documentary, corroborated
entries.content: Audit evidence supports conclusions. Sufficiency refers to the quantity of evidence (higher risk needs more). Appropriateness refers to evidence quality: relevance, validity, and reliability. Reliability improves if evidence is external, obtained directly by the auditor, in documentary form, and corroborated across sources.

entries.title: How Evidence is Collected (Techniques)
entries.content: Evidence may be collected using document scrutiny, physical inspection/site visits, observation of processes, questionnaires, surveys, confirmation from third parties, re-performance of procedures, and analytical procedures including data comparisons and outlier analysis.

entries.title: Scope Definition (What/Who/Where/Period)
key_points: What to audit (subject matter for regularity + propriety across units)
Who to audit (apex entity + selected audit units)
Which period to audit (typically since last audit, risk-driven)
entries.content: Audit scope defines what to audit, who to audit, where to audit, and which period to audit. Scope is shaped by risk and materiality. Typically the audit period covers time since previous audit, but may extend based on risk indicators or concerns.

entries.title: Audit Strategy vs Audit Plan (What Must Be Documented)
question_intents: difference between audit strategy and audit plan
what is included in audit plan
key_points: Strategy: environment, framework, users, materiality, risks, scope, objectives, criteria, sampling
Plan: units selection, implementing units sample, timing, team assignment, procedures, evidence
entries.content: Audit strategy defines the overall approach: entity environment, regulatory framework, intended users, materiality, risks, scope, objectives, criteria, and sampling considerations. Audit plan operationalizes execution: selected units, sample of implementing units, timing, team formation, task allocation, procedures, and evidence to be collected.

entries.title: Reporting Principles (How the Report Must Be Written)
question_intents: how should audit reports be written
key_points: Contradictory process (validate facts with entity and include responses where appropriate)
entries.content: Compliance audit reporting should follow completeness (consider all relevant evidence), objectivity (factually correct and balanced conclusions), timeliness (report in due time), and contradictory process (validate facts with auditable entity and incorporate responses where appropriate).

entries.title: Standard JSON Output Format for Your Compliance Agent
question_intents: tell me more about the requirements
entries.content: When answering compliance questions, always return a structured JSON response. If regulatory evidence is missing from retrieved context, mark the status as INSUFFICIENT_EVIDENCE and list what evidence is required. Keep findings grounded in retrieved context only.
